ygData.subject: Error compiling rtNEAT with gcc 4.1.3

Ken, I must have clicked on the wrong button.  I have been having some
prob=
lems trying to compile rtNEAT.  However, today I stumbled across a
solution=
.  I run ubuntu 7.10 at home and it has gcc 4.1.3,  This
version of gcc doe=
s not compile the rtNEAT code.  It gives the
following errors below.  Howev=
er, on my lunch break I tried using an
older version of gcc 3.4 and this wo=
rked fine.  When I got home
tonight, I installed gcc 3.4 on my home machine=
.  I tried compiling
the rtNEAT but got some different errors.  I then trie=
d the rtNEAT
that came with the dance evolution and that seemed to compile
=
correctly.  Do you know of any rtNEAT code that will compile with gcc
4.1.X=
 ?

              Best Regards

                   Ty

ll  -c network.cpp -o network.o

declared

no type

ror: extra qualification `NEAT::Network::' on member

 --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Tom McCallum <termcc@> wrote:

> > > Hi =
everyone,

> > > I have been trying to evolve networks using rtNEAT w=
hich will 
> learn a

g a real number 
> and the  
> > > inputs are timeseries.  Now I know that =
there exists a neural net
> > which  
> > > can do this to a high degree of=
 accuracy ( > 95% ) but cannot
> > reproduce  
> > > the results using rtNe=
at ( the C++ version) and wondered if I was

> > > something sil=
ly or if it simply cannot evolve a net to learn it.

re information on my scenario:
> > > 
> > > Inputs : {i1,i2,i3,...,iN}, all=
 of which are real numbers
> > > Target Output : T, which is a real number =
value between 0 and 1

> > > Here is the start genome:
> > > 
> > > g=
enomestart 1
> > > trait 1 0.1 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
> > > trait 2 0.2 0 0 0 0 0 0 =
0
> > > trait 3 0.3 0 0 0 0 0 0 0

> > > node 2 0 1 1
> >=
 > node 3 0 0 2
> > > gene 1 1 3 0.0 0 1 0 1
> > > gene 2 2 3 0.0 0 2 0 1
>=
 > > gene 3 3 3 0.0 0 2 0 1
> > > genomeend 1
> > > 
> > > and here are my =
parameters:
> > > 
> > > trait_param_mut_prob 0.5
> > > trait_mutation_powe=
r 1.0
> > > linktrait_mut_sig 1.0
> > > nodetrait_mut_sig 0.5

ut_power 2.5

eff 1.0

nce 1.0

_random_trait_prob 0.1

rait_prob 0.1

_prob 0.00
> > > mutate_gene_reenable_prob 0.000
> > > mutate_add_node_prob=
 0.03

> =
> > mate_multipoint_prob 0.6
> > > mate_multipoint_avg_prob 0.4

singlepoint_prob 0.0

 > pop_size 100

ry 30

> > > The fitness func=
tion is simply to minimise the difference 
> between the  
> > > output and=
 target values.  A winner is declared when a network 
> has at  
> > > leas=
t 80% accuracy.

> > > Unfortunately despite running numerous attempt=
s with varying 
> amounts
> > of  
> > > runs, population sizes, and other =
parameters it still struggles 
> to get  
> > > consistently above 60%.   I=
 know the structure required is a 
> recurrent  
> > > network with one hid=
den layer and it seems to get that far and 
> the
> > best it  
> > > can a=
chieve is 76% so far.  Could it be that the best networks 
> are
> > being =
 
> > > destroyed through too higher mutation / crossover?  Is it that I
> =
> need a  
> > > diferent fitness function, if so what kind should i be usi=
ng

> > should  
> > > I be separating the outputs into wider range=
s rather than 
> approximate
